Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Sensor & Actuator I/UCRC Phase III
Award.AbstractNarration:
1068017 University OF California-Berkeley; Richard Muller

BSAC is proposing a Phase III support (third five-year period) for the Center, including support for central personnel, evaluation and research. The lead of the proposed Center will be the University of California-Berkeley (UC-B) with a site at the University of California, Davis (UC-D).

BSAC was established in 1986, and is currently a self-sustaining Center that continues to operate under the IUCRC model. Since its founding, BSAC has been devoted to research on sensors and miniature moving mechanical elements or MEMS (MicroElectroMechanical Systems). The quality and impact of prior BASC research in MEMS is well known and acknowledged internationally. The research team at the Center is led by more than a dozen UC-B/UC-D faculty representing current thought leaders in MEMS as well as fast-track young faculty. The goals of BSAC include: creating a leadership Microsystems research environment, enhancing the educational experience of its graduate students, and reducing the time to commercialization of BSAC research via systematic progress in multiple phases of new technology formation.

The proposal includes emphasis on a number of laudable academic objectives. The I/UCRC research program is highly complementary to the MEMS academic focus at UC Berkeley. Weekly seminars facilitate intergroup connections. Technology transfer is well-addressed in the proposal, and the proposal references 25 start up companies that are stated to be tracked on the BSAC web site. Through the Phase III award, BSAC intends to lead a new phase of fundamental and innovation research in materials, processes, components, and systems leading to new technology-enabled business development.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This continuing Phase III I/UCRC award supports the Berkeley Sensor & Actuator Center at UC Berkeley and UC Davis. The overarching goal of this center since its founding in 1986, has been industry-relevant research and graduate education in materials, processes, devices, and systems leading to industry commercialization of microelectromechanical systems. BSAC has in the current award reporting period, sustained and extended its research and graduate educational environment through the collective efforts of 13 top-rank university research faculty, 150+ graduate student and postdoctoral researchers, an environment of collaboration, and access to a diverse group of 36 Industrial Members who are usually current or future market leaders in their segments.

 

BSAC has over 80 active projects currently.  Two important examples with significant technical merit and broader impacts are

A miniaturized, wireless multi-gas sensor platform.

This project has enabled and catalyzed a product commercialization partnership for the oil & gas industry among multiple BSAC industrial members and research intermediaries in an unprecedented multi-company Research Alliance. This program has in an 18-month period, resulted in successful proof of concept devices fabricated and replicated in university fabrication facilities and licensing of industry partners who are preparing commercial samples for field trials by other industry partner end-users. Technical Merit of this project includes miniaturized low power batch-fabricated sensor arrays of newly invented chemically-sensitive field effect transistors individually functionalized for different gas species, along with major progress toward a true single chip wireless “mote” (no external components) that includes system integration of communication, sensing, computation, and energy harvesting. Broader Impacts of this project include successful demonstration of a multi-company, university based “research ecosystem” comprised of BSAC researchers, industrial member companies, and small company contractors operating from within the University recharge microfabrication facility (“facilitated research intermediaries”).  This research-to-commercialization ecosystem has exploited previously untapped synergies among research entities, and will be replicated with other industry partners and university researchers for commercialization of other university research. The educational benefit of early exposure to the industrial development context by university graduate students and postdocs working on the project has been demonstrated as an important by-product of the ecosystem.

MEMS Ultrasonic Sensors for Consumer Electronics

This program has included several projects aimed at development and commercialization of MEMS ultrasonic sensors for (1) ranging, proximity and gesture sensing and (2) ultrasonic fingerprint sensors. (1) Ranging: Ultrasound sensors are widely used in industrial and automotive applications, such as the parking-assist sensors in cars. The ultrasound transducers used in these applications are based on a very old technology where bulk piezoelectric ceramic is bonded into a metal housing, and many discrete electronic components are used to transmit and receive ultrasound waves. Technical merit: The BSAC research team conducted fundamental research on MEMS ultrasonic sensors operating in air, leveraging MEMS manufacturing techniques and modern integrated circuit (IC) technology to create ultrasound sensors that are smaller, lower cost, and have ultra-low power-consumption. This I/UCRC project demonstrated MEMS phased-arrays of ultrasound transmitters and receivers capable of beam steering, allowing low power, highly miniaturized 3D free-space imaging effective over a range of distances up to one meter for such applications as gesture recognition and occupant detection.    Broader Impacts:  The commercialization effort has  involved BSAC researcher-membership collaborations and has resulted in technology commercialization both by participating industry members and through separate start-up company formation by Chirp Microsystems, a BSAC inspired startup and an NSF SBIR Phase II awardee. The launch of Chirp in particular represents NSF program success on 3 levels: a) BSAC I/UCRC membership funding of enabling technology, b) NSF SBIR funding of early stage Chirp technology, and c) NSF Funding to Chirp for subsidy of their BSAC I/UCRC membership through NSF supplement to their SBIR Phase II award. The collaborations of  BSAC faculty from Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at UC Davis and Electrical Engineering from UC Berkeley likewise illustrates the boundary-spanning collaboration strength of the I/UCRC program at its best.
